nodes.description: Richard Reid attempted to board AA Flight 63 from Paris to Miami on Friday without answering all security questions and was initially denied entry
nodes.support_text: Sources in France said that Reid attempted Friday to board an American Airlines Paris-to-Miami flight, but authorities at Charles de Gaulle Airport in Paris would not let him aboard when he did not answer all their questions.

nodes.description: French authorities reissued Reid's ticket after verifying his British passport and transferred him to American Airlines
nodes.support_text: allowed American Airlines to reissue the man's ticket for Flight 63 the next day

nodes.description: Reid ignited a match in his mouth during the flight and attempted to set fire to his shoes' inner tongue
nodes.support_text: a flight attendant smelled what she thought was a burnt match at about 11 a.m., 90 minutes into the flight... he put a match into his mouth

nodes.description: Flight attendants and passengers subdued Reid after he bit one attendant and struggled with multiple crew members
nodes.support_text: Moutardier then threw the water into the passenger's face. At that point, several other passengers joined in

nodes.description: Passengers sedated Reid with medical kits twice before the plane landed safely at Logan International Airport
nodes.support_text: two doctors among the passengers obtained sedatives from a medical kit on the plane and injected them into Reid -- repeating the process twice more

nodes.description: The FAA issued a security directive mandating random shoe inspections for all flights following the incident
nodes.support_text: as a result of Saturday's events, the Federal Aviation Administration issued a security directive

nodes.description: Reid was arraigned in U.S. District Court on Monday facing charges of interfering with flight crew duties
nodes.support_text: Richard C. Reid, 28, has been charged with interfering with the performance of the duties of flight crew members by assault or intimidation

nodes.description: U.S. Magistrate Judith Dein approved Reid's continued custody until the evidentiary hearing scheduled for Friday
nodes.support_text: U.S. Magistrate Judith Dein approved a request by U.S. attorneys for Reid to remain in custody until the pending trial

nodes.description: FBI identified Reid's shoes contained 10 ounces of unknown explosive material (Semtex/PETN/RDX pending analysis)
nodes.support_text: FBI's preliminary analysis of Reid's shoes showed they contained 'two functional improvised explosive devices'... about 10 ounces of an explosive substance

nodes.description: Reid made statements during restraint including 'It will happen the way it was written to happen'
nodes.support_text: Reid added: 'It will happen the way it's supposed to happen. The way it was written to happen'

nodes.description: The Boeing 767 with 197 people aboard was escorted by fighter jets to a safe landing in Boston
nodes.support_text: The Boeing 767 carrying 183 passengers and a crew of about 14 landed safely at 12:50 p.m. EST, escorted by U.S. fighter jets

nodes.description: Richard Reid attempted to board AA Flight 63 from Paris to Miami on Friday without answering all security questions and was initially denied entry
nodes.support_text: Sources in France said that Reid attempted Friday to board an American Airlines Paris-to-Miami flight, but authorities at Charles de Gaulle Airport in Paris would not let him aboard when he did not answer all their questions.

nodes.description: American Airlines Flight 63 was diverted to Boston's Logan International Airport following Reid's attack
nodes.support_text: The Boeing 767 carrying 183 passengers and a crew of about 14 landed safely at 12:50 p.m. EST, escorted by U.S. fighter jets
